thread.section_title: Press Enterprise : Riverside County California News, Sports and Entertainment
thread.title: MUSIC: 10 bands to listen to before It’s Not Dead festival
thread.title_full: MUSIC: 10 bands to listen to before It’s Not Dead festival - Press Enterprise

author: VANESSA FRANKO
title: MUSIC: 10 bands to listen to before It’s Not Dead festival
text:
BY VANESSA FRANKO / STAFF WRITER
Published: Oct. 8, 2015 Updated: 11:13 p.m. If you go When: Noon Saturday, Oct. 10.
Where: San Manuel Amphitheater, 2575 Glen Helen Parkway, Devore
Admission: $42.50 for general admission, plus fees.
Information: itsnotdeadfestival.com
Get ready to party like it’s Warped Tour in 1996. The It’s Not Dead Festival moshes onto the grounds of San Manuel Amphitheater in Devore on Saturday with a lineup that has pretty much every punk band that matters.
Co-produced by Kevin Lyman, who started the Warped Tour, the bands playing the main stage put out some of the best albums defining the genre in the ‘90s and beyond. Here’s your punk passport down memory lane with a primer of the main stage bands.
Don't forget to check out our interview with "Fat" Mike Burkett of NOFX .
1. Bad Religion
Bad Religion has carried the torch for Southern California punk for decades and will likely write the soundtrack to the apocalypse. Download before the show: “Suffer” and “Stranger Than Fiction” albums The fact you didn’t know: Singer Greg Graffin, who has a doctorate in zoology, is an author and taught classes at UCLA and Cornell. 2. NOFX
NOFX has been one of the stalwarts of punk, despite shunning mainstream radio. Download before the show: “Linoleum” and “Don’t Call Me White” The fact you didn’t know: Leader “Fat” Mike Burkett is a member of punk cover supergroup Me First and the Gimme Gimmes, along with members of Lagwagon, Swingin’ Utters and the Foo Fighters. 3. Descendents
Descendents showed that it was OK for punks to have feelings and sing about girls as well as Wienerschnitzel. Download before the show: “Milo Goes to College” and “Everything Sucks,” the complete albums. The fact you didn’t know: Singer Milo Aukerman did go to college and became a biochemist. 4. Pennywise
The bro punk rockers have reunited and legend has it if you hold a seashell up to your ear in their hometown of Hermosa Beach, you hear “Bro Hymn.” Download this before the show: “No Reason Why,” “Alien” and “Society.” The fact you didn’t know: When singer Jim Lindberg left the band in 2009, he started an alt rock group called The Black Pacific and Zoli Teglas from Ignite replaced him. Lindberg rejoined in 2012. 5. Lagwagon
The Goleta band’s early albums included covers of Creedence Clearwater Revival, Van Morrison and the “Inspector Gadget” theme, but the band quickly matured and tackled themes of adulthood with a pop-punk bent. Download before the show: “May 16,” “Razor Burn” The fact you didn’t know: Singer Joey Cape has produced The Ataris and Nerf Herder in addition to Lagwagon and his own side project Bad Astronaut. 6. The Bouncing Souls
These New Jersey punks sing of loyalty and brotherhood, as well as soccer and shark attacks. Download before the show: “Hopeless Romantic,” “Kate Is Great,” “Say Anything” The fact you didn’t know: Singer Greg Attonito has a side project with wife Shanti Wintergate called Play Date that plays children’s music.
7. Less Than Jake
This ska/punk hybrid from Florida performed “We’re All Dudes,” the theme song from the “Good Burger” movie. The band’s 1998 album “Hello Rockview” was among the best of the year. Download this before the show: “Look What Happened,” “Sugar in Your Gas Tank,” “All My Best Friends Are Metalheads” The fact you didn’t know: The band opened for Bon Jovi on the rock band’s “Crush” tour in 2000. 8. Reel Big Fish
With their tongues firmly planted in cheeks, Reel Big Fish invaded the mainstream as part of Orange County’s ska-inspired explosion in the ‘90s and even landed an on-screen role in the movie “Baseketball.” Download this before the show: “Sell Out,” “She Has a Girlfriend Now” and “Beer.” The fact you didn’t know: The band signed its major label record deal after a show at The Barn at UC Riverside. 9. Goldfinger
Goldfinger’s pop punk rise was aided by appearing on the soundtracks to popular video games, including the “Tony Hawk’s Pro Skater” series. Download this before the show: “Here in Your Bedroom” and “Superman” The fact you didn’t know: Bassist Kelly LeMieux also plays for Buckcherry. 10. Fishbone
Fishbone merged ska, funk and punk and the Los Angeles band now includes The Skeletones’ Paul Hampton on keyboards. Download this before the show: “Party at Ground Zero” and “Everyday Sunshine” The fact you didn’t know: The band appeared in the Frankie Avalon/Annette Funicello beach movie send-up “Back to the Beach” performing “Jamaica Ska” with Funicello.
1. Bad Religion
Bad Religion has carried the torch for Southern California punk for decades and will likely write the soundtrack to the apocalypse.
Download before the show: “Suffer” and “Stranger Than Fiction” albums
The fact you didn’t know: Singer Greg Graffin, who has a doctorate in zoology, is an author and taught classes at UCLA and Cornell.
2. NOFX
NOFX has been one of the stalwarts of punk, despite shunning mainstream radio.
Download before the show: “Linoleum” and “Don’t Call Me White”
The fact you didn’t know: Leader “Fat” Mike Burkett is a member of punk cover supergroup Me First and the Gimme Gimmes, along with members of Lagwagon, Swingin’ Utters and the Foo Fighters.
3. Descendents
Descendents showed that it was OK for punks to have feelings and sing about girls as well as Wienerschnitzel.
Download before the show: “Milo Goes to College” and “Everything Sucks,” the complete albums.
The fact you didn’t know: Singer Milo Aukerman did go to college and became a biochemist.
4. Pennywise
The bro punk rockers have reunited and legend has it if you hold a seashell up to your ear in their hometown of Hermosa Beach, you hear “Bro Hymn.”
Download this before the show: “No Reason Why,” “Alien” and “Society.”
The fact you didn’t know: When singer Jim Lindberg left the band in 2009, he started an alt rock group called The Black Pacific and Zoli Teglas from Ignite replaced him. Lindberg rejoined in 2012.
5. Lagwagon
The Goleta band’s early albums included covers of Creedence Clearwater Revival, Van Morrison and the “Inspector Gadget” theme, but the band quickly matured and tackled themes of adulthood with a pop-punk bent.
Download before the show: “May 16,” “Razor Burn”
The fact you didn’t know: Singer Joey Cape has produced The Ataris and Nerf Herder in addition to Lagwagon and his own side project Bad Astronaut.
6. The Bouncing Souls
These New Jersey punks sing of loyalty and brotherhood, as well as soccer and shark attacks.
Download before the show: “Hopeless Romantic,” “Kate Is Great,” “Say Anything”
The fact you didn’t know: Singer Greg Attonito has a side project with wife Shanti Wintergate called Play Date that plays children’s music.
7. Less Than Jake
This ska/punk hybrid from Florida performed “We’re All Dudes,” the theme song from the “Good Burger” movie. The band’s 1998 album “Hello Rockview” was among the best of the year.
Download this before the show: “Look What Happened,” “Sugar in Your Gas Tank,” “All My Best Friends Are Metalheads”
The fact you didn’t know: The band opened for Bon Jovi on the rock band’s “Crush” tour in 2000.
8. Reel Big Fish
With their tongues firmly planted in cheeks, Reel Big Fish invaded the mainstream as part of Orange County’s ska-inspired explosion in the ‘90s and even landed an on-screen role in the movie “Baseketball.”
Download this before the show: “Sell Out,” “She Has a Girlfriend Now” and “Beer.”
The fact you didn’t know: The band signed its major label record deal after a show at The Barn at UC Riverside.
9. Goldfinger
Goldfinger’s pop punk rise was aided by appearing on the soundtracks to popular video games, including the “Tony Hawk’s Pro Skater” series.
Download this before the show: “Here in Your Bedroom” and “Superman”
The fact you didn’t know: Bassist Kelly LeMieux also plays for Buckcherry.
10. Fishbone
Fishbone merged ska, funk and punk and the Los Angeles band now includes The Skeletones’ Paul Hampton on keyboards.
Download this before the show: “Party at Ground Zero” and “Everyday Sunshine”
The fact you didn’t know: The band appeared in the Frankie Avalon/Annette Funicello beach movie send-up “Back to the Beach” performing “Jamaica Ska” with Funicello.
Staff writer Dan Alegria contributed to this report.
Contact the writer: vfranko@pe.com or @vanessafranko on Twitter
